H « « origisiayt«4 f r o n t t h e r e c e i p t o f t h e a n n e x e d L e t t e r , a d d r e « s # t t
t o t h e IHantt&er o f thi«i T h e a t r e s —
" Bedford Street, Covent Garden p
J a n e 3Sth, 183S.
S I R , — B e i n g a lone stranger in this animated wilderness, London! I a m
nnder the neoessity of introducing myself to yoru notioe, with t h e hone t h a t yon*
good n a t u r e will pardon a T y r o s ambition, shonld i t even o'er-vanlt his discretion.
t hear t h e name, a n d am veritably a descendant of t h e F a m i l y of W I L L I A M
S H A K 8 P E A R E , of t h e E l i z a b e t h a n e r a , " "« e<*</or ail t,me!"~hnt" ^*--*.«» « **>*<?u
I have written two Drama*, one of which I wish to h a v e performed immediately, and to personate t h e hero, myself:—I wrote i t for t h e express purpose. A l l
I a s h of you, is to h e a t me read my Drama, a n d if you l i h e it, I will submittot h e
mote irksome ordeal of a c t i n g a Scene before yourself a n d critical Colleagues % if
you then t h i n k t h a t I h a v e merit, favor me with your p a t r o n a g e and s u p p o r t - b u t
if you decide t h a t I am an impostor, dismiss me with t h e contempt which I shall
then dosotve.'
Anxiously waiting your reply,
I am, Sir, your humble servant,
WILLIAM SHAKSPEARE."
T h e M a n a g e m e n t , d e s i r o u * to e a t e r N o v e l t y for t h e P u b l i c g r a t i f i c a t i o n , effected a n I n t e r v i e w w i t h (he W r i t e r o f t h e L e t t e r , t h e result,
o f w h i c h i»—that a n E n g a g e m e n t h a s b e e n e n t e r e d i n t o , a n d a

M
SIR,—Being a lone *trang*r in tat* anhnntad Nttldeiaeeo, Leaden! I am
nadar the necessity of introdnoiag aiytaif to yaw notice, with, the hope that year
good nature will pardon a Tyro's ambition, thonld it even ow-Tinlt hia diaorettetv
I hear the name, and am reritahly a doscendaat of the Faatily of W t X L I A N
SRAXSPEARE, of the Elixahethnn era," «* P**/* •« /««•'"-hat *' n*fi« ak(W-.a?"
I have written two Dramas, one of which I with to have performed immeAiajtely, and to personate the horo, myself:-! wrote it for the express purpose. Alt
I ask of yon, is to h«ar me read my Drama, and if yon like it, I will submit to the
more irksome ordeal of acting; a Scone before yourself and critical Colleagues- if
you then think that I have merit, favor me with your patronage and support -out
if you decide that I am an impostor, dismiss me With the contempt which I shall
then deserve."
Anxiously waiting your reply,
I am. Sir, your humble servant,
WILLIAM SHAKSPEARB.

e d f r o m t h e r e c e i p t o f t h e a n n e x e d L e t t e r , addrewKMi

to the Manager of this Theatre*-" Bedfoid Street, Coveut Garden,- Jane 25th, 1338."
" S I R , — B e i c g a Ion. stranger in this animated wilderness, London! I am
under the necessity of introducing rnyeelf to yonr notice, with the hope that yottr
good nature will pardon a Tyro's ambition, should it even o'er-vault his discretion.
I hear the name, and am veritably a descendant of tha Family of WILLIAM
8HAKSPEARJB, of the Elizabethan era, " "-<• i'oei/or 0n ,mr> ' - b u t ' **-**• M a mi*-*"
I have written two Dramas, one of which I wish to have performed immediately, and to personate the hero, myself:—! wrote it for the express purpose. AH
I ask of you, is to hear me read my Drama, and if you like it, I will submit to the
more Irksome ordeal of acting a Scene before yourself and critical Colleagnes i If
you then think that I have merit, favor me with ybot patronage and support-but
if you decide that I am an impostor, dismiss me with the contempt which I shall
then deserve.',
Anxiously waiting your reply, I am. Sir, your hnmble servant,
W I L L I A M SHAKSPEARB.

of w h i c h la—that a n E n g a g e m e n t h a s b e e n e n t e r e d i n t o , a n d - -

ENGLISH OPERA HOUSE,

MONDAY and TUESDAY, JANUARY 14 and 15, 1839,
WILL

TAKE

PI-ACE

PROMENADE CONCERTS
A LA

MUSARD.

In accordance with the daily increasing taste for Music in this country, the Management have resolved on adopting the
Plan pursued with such unexampled success in Paris, and will throw open the Theatre EVERY EVENING to the
Public, the Price of Admission to the PUBLIC BOXES, (except the Balcony Circle) the P I T and GALLERY, all of
which communicate with each other, being

O NE

SHILLING.

Places may be secured in the BALCONY CIRCLE, by application at the Box Office, on the payment of

T W O

S H I L L I N G S .

The P I T is Boarded over, and Refreshments of every description may be had within the House.

CONCERT

HERALD,

September

39th.

H O U S E . — T h e " Promenade Concerts,"

originally commenced at this h o u s e , were resumed here lust
n i g h t for the season. As t h e /inncipium
et fores, t h e source
from whence has issued t h e stream of harmony that is now
flowing through t h e town, this orchestra is entitled t o t h e
highest praise, and m u s t ensure, s o l o n g as the public is i n fluenced by sweet s o u n d s , the highest e n c o u r a g e m e n t a n d
s u p p o r t . T h e orchestra consists of CO performers, c o n d u c t e d b y Signor N e g r i , and led l>y T o l b e c q u o , the loader a t the
Italian Opera H o u s e , and comprises artists of a c k n o w l e d g e d
first-rate
excellence. D i n i n g t h e tecess, t h e s t a g e of t h e
t h e a t r e , over which an arched roof has been thrown, h a s been
handsomely d e c o r a t e d , a n d the walls embellished bv a series
of d e s i g n s and national illustrations in t h e style of W a t t e a u .
1 hey a r e very beautifully executed, and do great credit t o
t h e pencil of Mr. P . Phillips, the artist. A light wire g a u z e work h a s been thrown over the balcony, which will obviate
the inconvenience experienced from t h e extreme h e a t last
season.
T i e p r o g r a m m e of last evening contained s e l e c t i o n s from t h e w o r k s of Rossini, Mozart, Boildieu, M u s a r d ,
S t r u a s s , &c. T h e first part of t h e performance w a s opened
b y " G o d save t h e Queen,"' which was given in a m o s t e t f e c .
tive a n d beautiful m a n n e r , t h e solo portions being taken u p
by M r . B a u m a n n , G . C o o k e , and H a r p e r . In t h e c o u r s e of
t h e e v e n i n g a n e w waltz, fFitner
Gemuths, by S t r a u s s ; a
n e w quadrille, Les Martyrs,
by M u s a r d ; selections from
Rossini's opera of Guillaume
Tell, with solos for b a s soon, clarionet, a n d cortiet a piston, a r r a n g e d by S i g n o r
N e g i i , executed delieiously by Messrs. Baumann, Lazarus,
and L a u r e n t , j u n . ; a n d a new quadrille, entitled Momens de
Folie, written expressly for these concerts, by Balfe, w e r e
performed with t h e truest harmony. A solo on t h e bassoon
b y M r . Bauraann, w h o evoked t h e richest, the fullest, a n d
t h e s w e e t e s t t o n e s , was warmly a n d deservedly a p p l a u d e d .
W e m u s t not omit t o mention t h e performance of M r .
Lazarus on t h e c l a r i o n e t ; it was beautifully subdued, a n d
exquisitely sweet.

performers. M. Bautnann played a solo on t h e b a s s o o n '
which deservedly elicited t h e w a r m e s t a n d m o s t enthusiastic
a p p l a u s e . An o b l i g a t e , for t h e bassoon, w a s also i n t r o d u c e d

Tell, by N e g r i , and a n o t h e r
in a set of quadrilles composed " expressly for t h e s e c o n certs'' by Mr.Balfe. A l t o g e t h e r nothing could g o off better.
T h e choice of pieces w a s very g o o d , a n d N e g r i ' s selection
from Guillaume
Tell w a s loudly encored. T h e p r o m e n a d e
was so respectably a t t e n d e d , that t h e g e n t e e l could not find
an opportunity to sneer, nor t h e ill-natured t o condemn.

SUNDAY
TIMES,
October Uh.
Tho*Promenado B ind c o m m e n c e d operations on M o n d a y
ovening at t h e E n g l i s h O p e r a H o u s e , with great eclat, a n d
notwithstanding t b e w e a t h e r was very unfavorable, t h e
house was full.
1 h e house h a s been newly decorated, a n d
the orchestra improved in a p p e a r a n c e . T h e band consists
of sixty-one, including N e g r i , t h e c o n d u c t o r ; leader, T o l becque.
T h e r e a r e twenty violins, four tenors ( M o r a l t
p r i n c i p a l ) , five violoncellos, five contra-bassi (Anfossi p r i n cipal) with a complete c o m p l e m e n t of wind instruments. O n
Monday evening, t h e overture to La Gazxa Ladra ( R o s s i n i ) ,
Don Giovanni ( M o z a r t ) , a n d La Dame Bi<zne/ie(Boieldieu)
were m o s t admirably performed. Several quadrilles, waltzes
and g a l o p s , were given with g r e a t s p i r i t ; a new set ol q u a drilles, called " M o m e n s d e F o l i e , ' c o m p o s e d e x p r e s s l y
for this orchestra by Balfe, was successfully played, a n d a
selection taken from " Guillatime T e l l , " a r r a n g e d by N e g r i ,
in which there were brilliant solos for bassoon, clarionet
and cornel, most excellently performed by Baumaun, L a z a r u s
a n d L a u r e n t , .Jun., w a s loudly a n d deservedly encored ; a s
was a set of quadrilles by Dufrene.
In t h e course of t h .
e v e n i n g , M r . B a u m a n u played an a i r with variations on t h e
bassoon in capital style; it was a m o n g t h e best exhibitions
of t h e kind we ever h e a r d : h e m a d e n o t h i n g of s k i p p i n g
t h r e e octaves, that is, from D below t h e bass stave t o t ) in
alt, a n d t h e tone in t h e u p p e r part w a s truly beautiful. I t
were needless to a d d , that the performer was most r a p t u rously applauded by t h e whole h o u s ? . T h e p e r f o r m a n c e
o p e n e d with " G o d save t h e On-sen,*' played t h r e e t i m e s
o v e r : t h e first time a s a solo, very s w e e t l y , by G . C o o k e ,
on t h e o b o e ; t h e second, on the b a s s o o n , by B a u m a n n ; a n d
t h e third, on the t r u m p e t , by H a r p e r . '1 h e solo p l a y e r s
a n n o u n c e d for the week w e r e Richardson (flute) and L:izarus
(clar.onet).

SOLO

MORNING
ENGLISH

M u s a r d , t h e English Opera band, re-commenced their season last night, a n d with every p r o s p e c t of success ; for t h e
t h e a t r e , though most unpropitious t o t h e d r a m a , t h o u g h
s t a m p e d with theatrical ill-luck, h a s proved p r o s p e r o u s
e n o u g h for u n d r a m a t i c music. T h i s is t h e third season,
and t h e m a n a g e r s beginning to find themselves at h o m e ,
have thought about decorating their establishment—of c o n sulting the eyes a s well as t h e ears of t h e visitors. Last year
the s t a g e w a s merely adorned with coulisses, and backed
with a scone from t h e Farmer s Story ; now t h e m a n a g e r s
h a v e swept oil' theatrical debris—flies no longer a r e s u s pended from a b o v e , but an a r a b e s q u e ceiling covers t h e
s t a g e ; t h e walls a r e adorned with landscapes {tainted in
medallions. A l t o g e t h e r , with removing this, and i n t r o d u c i n g
that, t h e m a n a g e r s have completed a very pleasing locality,
w h e r e t h e lounging lovers of music may stroll a b o u t and
enjoy t h e combined felicities of melody and g o s s i p . T h e
band is t h e same a s heretofore—Signor N e g r i the conductor,
M o n s . T o l b e c q u e t h e leader ; Messrs. Harper, Piatt, B a u m a n n , Laurent, j u n . , nnd Richardson are a m o n g t h e solo

October Md.

T h e original " P r o m e n a d e C o n c e r t s " commenced their t h i r d
season a t the E n g l i s h O p e r a H o u s e on Monday e v e n i n g ,
and with every p r o s p e c t of a highly successful season. T h e
T h e a t r e h a s been newly d e c o r a t e d in a very beautiful a n d
e l a b o r a t e style. T h e roof over t h e orchestra is in t h e form
of an arch, with rich m o u l d i n g s , a s h a p e admirably a d a p t e d
for s o u n d : and t h e s t a g e and orchestra a i e hud out so
that each compartment forms a picture, after the ma unci of
W a t t e a u , the effect b e i n g extremely good. T h e o r c h e s t r a
has been remodelled, a n d goes with a d m i r a b l e precision and
effect, T o l b e c q u e b e i n g t h e leader, and N e g r i t h e e o n d u c t o r .
N o t h i n g , indeed, c u surpass t h e way t h e soli passages were
played by B a u m a n n , G . Cooke, Emile, Laurent, J la rper,
and H a t t o n .
i h e selection was much t h e same a s t h e p r e ceding seasons, t h e novelties b e i n g a n e w set of Q u a d r i l l e s
by M u s a r d , from Donizetti's last O p e r a " L e s Martyr*," a n d
a n e w s e t c o m p j s e d expressly b y Balfe, called " M o m e n s d e
Folie, 1 ' which was received with much a p p l a u s e . T h e s o l o s
for t h e different instruments a r e written with much t a s t e , a n d
were m o s t excellently p l a y e d ; indeed, t h e whole p e r f o r m ances could leave n o t h i n g for t h e most fastidious t o desire.
